description: Check if you need a certificate to export animal feed or pet food, and other rules you must follow.

details.body:
This guidance applies to businesses in Great Britain (GB) (England, Scotland and Wales) exporting or moving animal feed and pet food to, or through:

  • the EU
  • non-EU countries
  • Northern Ireland (NI)

You need an export health certificate (EHC) to export animal feed and pet food made from products of animal origin(POAO).

You may also need a certificate of free sale if you’re exporting to non-EU countries. The food authority in the country you’re exporting to will tell you if you need one.

You need to follow different rules if you’re exporting animal feed or pet food that contains animal by-products (ABP).

Export or move live animal feed and pet food to the EU or NI

You need an EHC to:

  • export animal feed and pet food from GB to the EU
  • move animal feed and pet food from GB to Northern Ireland (NI)
  • transit through the EU and NI

You also need to:

  • get your goods checked at an EU border control post (BCP) or NI point of entry in the first country you enter
  • make sure your EU or NI-based import agent has notified the BCP or NI point of entry that your consignment is arriving - check with the BCP or NI point of entry for how much notice needs to be given
  • comply with wider HMRC guidance on customs requirements for exporting to the EU
  • follow HMRC guidance for moving goods from GB to NI

General exporting rules

Make sure you follow wider business guidance for exporting to the EU.

Check if you need an EHC

Check the EHC finder to see if a certificate exists for your animal feed or pet food.

If you find an EHC, follow the EHC process to export.

If you cannot find an EHC, you’ll need to contact the competent authority in NI or the EU country you’re exporting to, in advance, to find out what:

  • paperwork you’ll need to fill in
  • rules you need to comply with

The competent authority means the equivalent of the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs in the EU country you’re exporting to. DAERA is the competent authority in NI.

If the competent authority says that you need an EHC, you’ll need to get their import conditions. Contact APHA who’ll arrange an EHC for you.

If you’re moving agrifood goods to NI, you do not need to pay for them to be inspected and certified. The certifier invoices the government for these costs as part of the Movement Assistance Scheme.

Checks at EU BCPs or point(s) of entry in NI

You must get animal feed or pet food containing products of animal origin (POAO) checked at an EU BCP or point of entry in NI.

These checks are made to protect:

  • animal health and welfare
  • public health

Your goods may be refused entry, seized, destroyed or returned to GB if they arrive at an EU port without a BCP or EU BCP or NI point of entry:

  • where checks cannot be carried out
  • that cannot check your type of product
  • without the correct documentation

Find the correct BCP or NI point of entry for your goods

You must find a BCP or NI point of entry that accepts animal feed or pet food containing POAO as not all BCPs and points of entry accept all goods. You’ll need to consider how to redirect your trade route if needed.

There are more than 400 BCPs in the EU and they’re usually at EU ports and airports.

Check the full list of full list of EU BCPs and NI points of entry.

Give advance notice to EU BCPs or point(s) of entry in NI

You’ll need to give EU BCPs or points of entry in NI advance notice of goods arriving.

Check with the BCP or point of entry you’re planning to use for how much notice is needed.

Contact your import agent in the EU or NI to make sure they notify the BCP through Trade Control and Expert System (TRACES) of the arrival of the consignment.

They must do this within the time limits set out by the BCP or point of entry.

What happens if your goods fail inspection at an EU BCP or NI point of entry

If your goods fail inspection because of risks to animal or public health, they will be destroyed immediately.

If the goods fail for other reasons, the BCP or point of entry will:

  • notify your importer or agent
  • ask them to decide whether your goods should be destroyed or returned to GB

The BCP or point of entry will not usually contact you directly.

EU listing for exporters and suppliers

You need to be listed as an approved business with the EU if you export food that contains POAO.

If you would like your establishment to be listed, contact the ABP team on 03000 200 301 or email them at CSCOneHealthABP@apha.gov.uk.

Export to non-EU countries

You usually need to complete an EHC and some supporting documents to export animal feed and pet food that contains POAO to non-EU countries.

You may also need a certificate of free sale.The country you’re exporting to will tell you if you need one.

Check the EHC finder to see if a certificate exists for your product.

If you find an EHC, follow the EHC process to export.

If you cannot find an EHC for your product, you’ll need to contact the competent authority in the EU country you’re exporting to, in advance, to find out what:

  • paperwork you’ll need to fill in
  • rules you need to comply with

If the competent authority says that you need an EHC, you’ll need to get their import conditions. Email the conditions to APHA at exports@apha.gov.uk who’ll arrange an EHC for you.

Apply for a certificate of free sale

To apply for a certificate of free sale you should:

  • save a copy of the application form to your computer
  • fill in all relevant parts, then email it to trader@rpa.gov.uk

Valid forms are processed within 5 working days of receiving them. You should allow 10 working days from sending your application to receiving your certificate(s) back.

It’s free to apply and the certificates do not expire unless the country you’re exporting to specifies a time limit.

If you need help

Contact the Rural Payments Agency (RPA). Rural Payments Agency Telephone: 03300 416 500 Monday to Friday: 8:30am to 5pm Find out about call charges.

Export feed made from animal products to non-EU countries via an EU country

Animal feed containing POAO destined for non-EU countries that transit the EU will need an:

  • EU Transit Certificate, held on the EHC finder - if you cannot find one, contact APHA
  • EHC for the final destination (the non-EU country)

You’ll need an EU importer who will take responsibility for the consignment while it’s transiting the EU.

You’ll also need to check HMRC guidance on any customs declarations you’ll need to make.

change_history.note: Removed the sections on returned and rejected goods as not applicable to animal feed and pet food.
Information added to explain the changes to the exports process from 1 Jan 2021.
Application form updated to be made accessible
This guidance has highlighted Brexit update link, and streamlined content for ease of reading.
Added information for exporters about how to get an export health certificate if the UK leaves the EU without a deal.

contents.text: Follow these steps if you're moving goods permanently from:

contents: @{text=England, Wales or Scotland (Great Britain) to a country outside the UK}
@{text=Northern Ireland to a country outside the UK and the EU}

contents.text: What you need to do is different if you are:

contents: @{href=https://www.gov.uk/guidance/trading-and-moving-goods-in-and-out-of-northern-ireland-from-1-january-2021; text=moving goods between Great Britain and Northern Ireland or Northern Ireland and the EU}
@{href=https://personal.help.royalmail.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/106; text=sending goods through the post (Royal Mail guidance)}
@{href=/take-goods-sell-abroad; text=taking a small amount of goods personally to sell abroad}
@{href=/taking-goods-out-uk-temporarily; text=taking goods temporarily out of the UK}
@{href=https://www.great.gov.uk/advice/; text=Learn about exporting, including making export plans, on great.gov.uk}

steps.title: Check if you need to follow this process

contents: @{href=/check-duties-customs-exporting; text=Check duties, rules and restrictions for your goods in the destination country}

steps.title: Check the rules for exporting your goods

contents.text: There are special rules and you may need to get licences or certificates if you are exporting any of the following:

contents: @{href=/government/collections/guidance-on-exporting-live-animals-or-animal-products; text=animals and animal products}
@{href=/government/collections/importing-and-exporting-plants-and-plant-products; text=plants and plant products}
@{href=/guidance/export-drugs-and-medicines-special-rules; text=drugs and medicines}
@{href=/guidance/export-medical-devices-special-rules; text=medical devices}
@{href=/guidance/export-chemicals-licences-and-special-rules; text=chemicals}
@{href=/guidance/applying-for-a-licence-to-import-or-export-ozone-depleting-substances; text=ozone-depleting substances and F-gases}
@{href=/guidance/controls-on-radioactive-sources; text=radioactive substances}
@{href=/guidance/export-diamonds-special-rules; text=diamonds}
@{href=/guidance/export-art-antiques-and-cultural-goods-special-rules; text=art works, antiques and culturally significant goods}
@{href=/guidance/importing-and-exporting-waste; text=waste shipments}
@{href=/guidance/controls-on-torture-goods; text=goods that could be used for torture or capital punishment}
@{href=/guidance/firearms-and-export-control-forms; text=firearms, ammunition and related equipment}
@{href=/guidance/export-controls-military-goods-software-and-technology; text=military goods, services and technology}
@{href=/guidance/export-controls-dual-use-items-software-and-technology-goods-for-torture-and-radioactive-sources; text=items that can have both civil and military uses}

steps.title: Apply for any licences you need to export your goods

contents.text: You need an EORI number that starts with GB to export goods from England, Wales or Scotland.
If you move goods to or from Northern Ireland you may need one that starts with XI.

contents: @{href=/eori; text=Get an EORI number}
@{href=/vat-registration/when-to-register; text=Check if you need to register for VAT}

contents.text: There are processes that can make clearing customs quicker and easier to manage if you export goods regularly.

contents: @{href=/guidance/using-simplified-declarations-for-exports; text=Find out about using simplified declaration procedures}
@{href=/guidance/what-you-need-to-move-goods-between-or-through-common-transit-countries-including-the-eu; text=Check if you can use Common Transit to move your goods}
@{href=/guidance/authorised-economic-operator-certification; text=Check if Authorised Economic Operator status is right for you}

steps.title: Get your business ready to export

contents.text: The business or person receiving the goods may need:

contents: @{text=to make an import declaration in their country}
@{text=licences or certificates to receive goods from the UK}

contents.text: Check whoever you are sending the goods to is able to import them into their country.

steps.title: Check whoever's receiving the goods can import them

contents.text: You can hire someone to deal with customs and transport the goods for you, or you can do it yourself.

contents: @{href=/guidance/appoint-someone-to-deal-with-customs-on-your-behalf; text=Find out how to hire someone to deal with customs for you}
@{href=/export-customs-declaration; text=Find out how to make export declarations yourself}
@{href=/transport-goods-from-uk-by-road; text=Find out how to transport goods out of the UK by road}

steps.title: Decide who will make export declarations and transport the goods

contents.text: You must find the right commodity code to classify the goods you're exporting.
Your customs agent or transporter might be able to help you with this.

contents: @{href=/guidance/finding-commodity-codes-for-imports-or-exports; text=Find the right commodity code for your goods}

contents.text: The completed invoice and any licences or certificates must travel with the goods.

When filling in the value of your goods on the invoice, use the price you’re selling them for. If you're not selling the goods, use the market value of the goods. List any freight or export insurance you included in the price separately.
You may need proof of origin if exporting to a country where your goods have a reduced or zero rate of duty.

contents: @{href=/guidance/get-proof-of-origin-for-your-goods; text=Get proof of origin for your goods}

contents.text: You might be able to zero rate the goods for VAT. This means you can charge your customers VAT at 0%.

contents: @{href=/guidance/vat-on-goods-exported-from-the-uk-notice-703; text=Check if you can zero rate the goods for VAT}

steps.title: Prepare the invoice and other documentation for your goods

contents.text: If you've appointed someone to deal with UK customs for you, they'll make the declaration and get your goods through the UK border.

contents: @{href=/export-customs-declaration; text=Make an export declaration and get your goods cleared by UK customs}

contents.text: You may need other documentation to get your goods into the destination country. Ask the person or business buying your goods what information you need to provide.

contents: @{href=/guidance/returning-goods-to-the-uk; text=Check how to bring goods back into the UK if they were rejected for import at another country’s border}

contents.text: You must keep commercial invoices and any customs paperwork.
If you're VAT registered, record the goods in your VAT accounts even if they are zero-rated.

contents: @{href=/vat-record-keeping/vat-account; text=Find out how to record the goods in your VAT accounts}

contents.text: If you exported controlled goods, for example firearms, keep the paperwork that shows who owns the goods.
